div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.

div.head: GERMANY AND AMERICA.
div.p: The following interesting article is published in the “Pall Mall Gazette.” The writer is an American citizen : -

Britishers have been much exercised in their minds of late over the tremendous exertions which for some time past Germany has been making to acquire a powerful navy. They are convinced that its ultimate purpose is to facilitate an armed descent of the mailed fist upon these islands. Such apprehensions, in view of the propinquity of the menace, are natural. It may, however, somewhat lessen these fears to learn that others consider them- selves possessed of equal, if not superior, cause for vigilance in the same direction. Briefly, all thinking Americans are not only keeping a very sharp eye on the abnormal activity in the Teuton dockyards, but have quite made up their minds as to the ob- jective —or at least one—of the leviathan German battle fleet that will take the seas in a few years’ time. The presence of Mr. Secre tary Root in South America, where he has been making an extensive political tour, is practical evidence of this conviction. The States, in fact are not going to be caught napping, but it is doubtful if Mr. Root would have been sent off on so pronounced a pilgrimage just now had not the internal affairs of the Southern Continent in their growing relationship to the outside world of both Europe and Asia given sufficient cause for alarm to render some counter move on the part of the States imperatively called for, if they were not to wait until a political earth- quake suddenly altered the map of their half of the Americas. As Americans we are well aware that we have at our doors one of the greatest unsolved political problems of this planet. For in that vast expanse of the earth’s surface which stretches from Panama to the Horn the statesmen and politicians of the world have long looked upon a vast dreary desert of intrigue and corruption, only inter- rupted at intervals here and there by an oasis of industry and activity. Not, indeed, without a measure of just impatience has a world, in which existence is obedient to the stern law of the survival of the fittest, viewed the neglect of a huge continent, equipped by Nature on a lavish and colossal scale to bear a tremendous part in the upward struggle of human civilization and progress.

But although circumstances have enabled it hitherto to escape any sudden or violent form of reformation, yet there are signs that this huge portion of the earth’s surface, with its magnificent possibilites, is silently and gra- dually being subjected to influences which cannot fail to impel it into the full vortex of civilised racial competition ; and that these congeries of unprogressive republics, which have hitherto preserved their existence in de- fiance of all the laws of nature, are just be- ginning to realise that the world has been more interested in them than they have been in themselves. Brazil has only lately awakened to the fact that the German colonies, which have been founded for the most part at the expense of the Rio Government, are assuming such proportions as to constitute a danger to Brazilian supremacy. Colonies of Asiatics also —for the Japanese are coming in numbers apparently to stay in Argentina—are springing up in almost every quarter of the great empty continent. Lost in the vast expanse of South America, these colonies are in a great measure governing themselves by laws of their own making, and avoiding as far as possible any contact with the customs and manners of their South American rulers. In the vast empty spaces of the great Southern Continent the difficulties still surrounding travel and inter communication are so great that the iudolent politicians of the capital are supremely ignorant of the outlying provinces, to say nothing of maintaining any touch with them. An amusing instance of this ignorance oc curred a little while ago. When the railway which the Argentine Government is endeavour- ing to push through Patagonia to Punta Arenas reached the Chubut Valley, the officials were dumbfounded to discover a population of some 30,000 Welshmen, of whose existence nothing had previously been known in Buenos Ayres. These Welsh colonies had grown up in the course of the last twenty years ; Welsh was spoken, and the colonists, it would seem had not the remotest idea that the territory they occupied had anything to do with the Argentine until the tax-gatherers were hurried through by the first train from the capital. We have got to recognise a situation arising from the fact that South America, in spite of its decadent Spanish peoples, is being rapidly colonised by vigorous races who, as in the case of the European colonists, consist for the most part of races more socially efficient than the owners of the land; that these incoming races bring with them a sense of superiority, and exhibit an inclination to maintain their liberties and defend their rights. They cannot be assimilated by the digestive powers of a less vigorous race, and as a result South America has been covered by a parasitic growth of alien nationalities. We shall better appreciate this process and its full meaning as an international political factor if we look for

a moment at Brazil. We shall there see the process within measurable distance of its logical conclusion-foreign intervention. Yet, in spite of the alarm which is at last felt by the Rio Government at the growing numbers and power of the German colonists, the Brazilian people as a whole are less animated by what we call patriotism than even the Chinese. The latter certainly do hate the foreign devil, whereas the native Brazilian re- gards the foreigner who comes to his shores as a very superior being, an appreciation which is apt to be correct. As for the wealthy and educated Brazilian who visits Europe and spends his time in Paris, he is a thorough citizen of the world. I have known one of them declare that the only hope for the proper development of Brazil would be the division of his country between the Powers. “All of us” he said, "the planters and commer- cial classes as well, would like to see the northern States pass under the pro- tection of the United States, the country from Pernambuco to Rio go to Great Britain, San Paolo to Italy, and Southern Brazil under Germany.” The singular thing is that while the South American Republics have long exhi- bited decidedly hostile sentiments towards the United States, they have seemed incapable of realising the peril which, cuckoo like, is growing up in their midst. The States might have protected them from armed attack, but for defence against this peaceful penetration they can only depend upon themselves. Throughout the southern provinces of Brazil German ex- ploring expeditions are constantly passing to and fro. The Germans say little, publish nothing, and accomplish much. These expedi- tions, moreover, are not financed by the Ger- man “colonies” on the spot, but by the Govern- ment and great merchant houses of the Father- land ; and thus the German people have practically become lords and masters of 8,000 square miles of Brazilian territory. Already 500,000 Germans are resident in Brazil, and, in spite of Brazilian citizenship, German ideals and the German spirit are inviolably pre- served. In South Brazil they have indeed become the ruling element. German fac- tories, warehouses, shops, farms, schools sub- sidised by the German Government, and churches dot the country everywhere; and German has superseded Portuguese, the official language, in scores of communities, where native Brazilians and negroes may be heard speaking in the broadest German dialects. Twenty million pounds of vested interests claim the protection of the Kaiser's flag. A cross-country railway and an even more ex- tensive projected system is in the hands of German capitalists. The country's vast ocean traffic, the Amazon river shipping, and much of the coasting trade are dominated by Germans. The mighty virgin wealth of Brazil fulfils all the German dreams of a rich colonial empire overseas, with power to expand over half a continent. Towards this goal the Germans are marching with a patient, plodding, determined precision which, while disclaiming any inten- tion of territorial aggrandisement, is so paving the way for territorial conquest that it will be a political move of the very simplest when the moment for the achievement is ripe. Thus, while German professors are consigning the Monroe doctrine to an imaginary scrap-heap, German bankers, shippers, merchants, manufac- rers, and colonising syndicates are engaged in restless efforts to Germanise Brazilian trade and to honeycomb the land with undiluted Germanism in the shape of German settle ments. This is the hour, therefore, in which North American statesmen most decide whe ther they will accept the fact of a future German empire in South America or not. For nothing less is plainly projected when influential Germans can talk of penalising German emigration to any other country but Brazil ; of “guaranteeing settlers there an absolutely undisturbed development”; of “per- mitting the country to enjoy as great a degree of self government as possible under officials raised and educated there” ; of “organizing a colonial army in Brazil in which every man can serve his time without returning to Germany"; and finally of “granting to this Germanized Brazil preferential tariffs.” "Then within a few years,” declares the German authority I am quoting, “we shall see rise on the other side of the Atlantic a mighty German colonial empire, which shall become the finest and most en- during colonial enterprise old Europe ever created.”

This dream of a Teuton transatlantic empire through the pacific penetration of South America is fall of unmistakable menace for the whole of Anglo-Saxon North America, and the States can never contemplate the foundation of a second Germany at their doors, with its hopeless complication of all the unsolved pro- blems of the Western hemisphere. Aware of this, Germany is creating a great navy ; but, for the States, forewarned is forearmed, and in the meantime, as evidenced by the journey of Mr. Root, they will fight Germany with her own weapons.
The Ministry of the Interior has issued a notice containing fall devils of the arrange ments in connection with the forthcoming pilgrimage.

On Wednesday afternoon a student of Al Idjtihel School, Boulac, was crushed to death by the fall of a tree trunk which had been cut down. It had been piled up with some other timber and rolled over on to the un- fortunate youth.

In order to give an impetus to normal education, the Ministry of Public Instruction has decided to allow every school girl boarder a monthly gratification of two pounds. A nor- mal school for girls has been opened at Darb- El-Gamamiz, and it has started with fifteen pupils, each of whom enjoy this grant.

The number of vehicles of the Egyptian State Railway Co. fitted with the vacuum brake at the end of 1905 was 830. During the year 57 vehicles were so fitted. Five other coaches were fitted with vacuum pipes only, making a total of 36. Only 104 coaching vehicles are now unfitted for use with this brake.

In the name of the passengers of an Austrian Lloyd mailboat, the Austrian Vice Consuls at Cairo and Alexandria, who were travelling by the same steamer, have lodged a protest with the Austrian Embassy at Rome, against the rough treatment to which their luggage was subjected by the Customs officials at Brindisi, on the arrival of the mailboat there on Monday week.

The new Inwards Sorting Sidings at Forn- el-Gueraya have been commenced. In the goods yard two cotton platforms have been extended 140 metres each, and a further one, 400 metres long, entirely constructed. 5,860 square metres of paving have been done. A shed for cotton platforms covering an area of 5,000 square metres has been construccted. Another shed of an area of 11,700 square metres is in hand. The expenditure under this head has amounted to L.E. 17,123.

All sorts of rumours are current in Constan- tinople regarding Nedjib Pasha Melhamé, the Sultan's confidential negotiator, who has sud- denly left, ostensibly for Carlsbad. It is now known that he has gone to Marienbad. Accord- ing to some reports be is entrusted with a mission to Prince Ferdinand regarding Bul- garian affairs. Others say he will try to discover King Edward’s attitude towards changing the Turkish succession, whilst others declare the object is to arrange a supply of mineral water for the Sultan’s use. The Sultan always employs Nedjib for delicate negotiations, but seldom succeeds, as in the Akabah question, when Sir Nicholas O’Conor refused to discuss the matter with him.

Two letters appeared in our columns recently, which are based on Dr. Sornac’s mummy origin of tuberculosis, and allege that inasmuch as the new quay soil was trans- ported thither from the neighbourhood of the ancient eastern necropolis of Alexandria at Chatby, considerable danger will ensue to the city. The anxiety appears to arise from the fact that as this soil is blown about by the wind millions of germs are thus disse- minated about the city. Fortunately the ar- chaeological substratum on which this alarm- ing theory is founded is at fault as at the epoch during which the necropolis at Chatby was used for interments the mummifying of bodies had ceased for many generations past. The hundreds of bodies interred at the Chatby burial ground were merely interred in the soil and all possibilities of infection have consequently passed away many hundreds and hundreds of years ago. Nowadays the only remnants of the corpses which were interred there in thousands are a few bones, which crumble into dust at the least touch, and some cinerary vases of terracotta, many of which can be seen at the Alexandria Museum.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be nonsuited by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Ap- plications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: THE AKABA DISPUTE.
POLICY OF THF PORTE
div.p: Constantinople September 6.
The Porte does not support some of the pretensions of tho Ottoman Commissioners regarding the Sinaitic Peninsula. (Havas

This attitude of the Porte is significant, and may be preliminary to a capitulation. On the other hand it may only be due to a desire to gain time for indulging in protracted negotia- tions between the Ottoman delegates and Constantinople. But in all probability there has been a deadlock, and the Porte has now discovered a nice excuse tor withdrawing from an impossible situation.
In commenting on the present position of the Akabah question the “Temps” says :—

“When the Iradé of May T4 was published settling the question of the contested frontier between Turkey and Egypt the British Press sang victory, and we joined in the congratula- tions which the British Government received from its friends as we had joined in the defence of the cause. No account had been taken of the everlasting duplicity of the Porte. Yet the director of the Ottoman Agency, in comment- ing upon the Iradé, wrote on May 25, ’Pyrrhic victory! Within a few days we shall see the Continental papers admitting that alter all the victor in the diplomatic tourney is rather the Ottoman Empire than England.’ The expedient which Abdul Hamid’s ad- visers had found is as follows :—The agree- ment had been arrived at by means of an arrangement for the delimitation of the frontier by a mixed commission. It was neces- sary to carry out the delimitation for the benefit of the Porte. The Note handed to Sir N. O’Conor stated that this delimitation would take place ‘approximately’ on the bases of the Firman of Investiture of 1892. The British Ambassador paid no heed to this adverb. He had soon to regret it. The Otto- man commissioners met their Egyptian and English colleagues at Akabah, and the most most charming courtesy characterized the early days of their labours. The Turks were too well advised to reopen the question of the oasis and village of Tabah, the point of departure of the whole incident. They were well aware that the delegates of the Khedive would admit no concession in that part of the frontier zone. It was elsewhere that they would seek to encroach upon Egyptian territory. Were they not invited to do so by the adverb ’approximately’? They took care not to lose the opportunity. In their aversion for straightforwardness whether of line or negotia- tion they traced the frontier from El Arish to Akabah in an arc of a circle penetrating 40 kilomètres into Egyptian territory west of the absolutely straight line. The English and Egyptians protest. The Turks stick to their scheme and are waiting with the traditional inertia which they know how to maintain in all litigation and conflicts. That is where the matter stands. It is significant of the methods of the Porte. It is to be hoped that this exam- ple will not be forgotten when the question of delimiting other frontiers arises—that, for instance, of Tripoli. The distrust of Turkish adverbs is the beginning of wisdom.”

div.head: DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Suez, September 6th.

H.R.H. the Duke of the Abruzzi is passen- ger on board the M.M. steamer “Natal” due to arrive at Suez to-morrow at noon from East Africa. The Duke and suite will disembark at Port Said and thence embark for Italy, after a very successful expedition on Mount Ruvenzori, the height of which was found to be 16,000 feet

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: A Sudanese inhabiting the Moharrem Bey quarter of Alexandria has been taken to hospital suffering from bubonic plague.
At Suez a plague patient has been admitted to hospital, and one death from plague has occurred outside the hospital.

The Moss liner “Amasis” sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here early next week.

div.head: THE PRINCE AND HELBAWI.
NATIVE PRESS CAMPAIGN.
div.p: The incident between Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha and Helbawi Bey which is said to have taken place on board the "Hoherzollern,” is continuing to afford plenty of “copy” to the vernacular press.

"Al Lewa” declares that "Al Moayad” ought to have refrained from publishing Hel- bawi Bey’s categorical contradiction of "Al Minbar.” "Al Lewa” consider that "Al Moayad” is “particeps criminis” with Hel- bawi for inasmuch as that newspaper dared to publish the Bey’s letter it must be con- sidered an accessory after the fact. This argu- ment of "Al Lewa” is interesting as showing the native journalist’s very elementary notions as to truth. Helbawi Bey wrote to "Al Moayad” flatly contradicting the false statements of "Al Minbar” respecting the conduct of Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha towards Helbawi Bey and “Al Lewa” is therefore indignant with "Al Moayad” because it published a true statement of the case.

"Al Minbar” it somewhat apologetic and argues that the conversation of the Prince with Mr. de Guerville as published in "New Egypt” tends to show that the Prince’s semi-official posi- tion would not prevent him from displaying his indignation with the part Helbawi played in the Denishwai affair. Therefore there are à priori reasons for the probability of the Prince behaving towards Helbawi on the "Hoher zollern” in the manner to which "Al Minbar” gave publicity. We congratulate our contemporary on the amazing sophistry of its justification for having published an untrue story.

div.head: OBITUARY.
DR. MAX EYTH.
div.p: From Ulm comes the news of the death on August 28 of Dr. Max Eyth, formerly engineer to Prince Halim Pasha. He was born at Kirch- heim-unter-Teck (Wurtemberg) on May 6, 1836. Having studied as a practical engineer, he went to England in 1861, and there became acquainted with John Fowler, who in that year founded the great steam plough factory at Leeds. At the end of 1862 he set out for British India to introduce steam culture there, but stopped in Egypt, where he was for four years chief engineer to Prince Halim Pasha. In 1866 Max Eyth returned to England and served with Messrs. Fowler until 1882, when he retir- ed and returned to Germany. There he founded, on the English pattern, the German Agricultu- ral Society and placed his experience and energy at the disposal of that society and its cause. Ten years later be retired into private life at Ulm. There he devoted himself to literary work.

div.head: EGYPT’S IRON & STEEL IMPORTS
div.p: The following table gives the comparative shares of the various nations in the wrought iron and steel imports into Egypt for 1905 :-

From the above it will be seen that, while we do less than three times as much as Germany, Belgians is far ahead of us. This is not as it should be, and proves conclusively that the warning sounded recently in “African Engineer- ing” is much needed. The above total for last year of wrought iron and steel imports records a steady growth since 1901 :-
It is therefore clear that this trade is worth looking after.

div.head: THE OSMANIEH “AT HOME.”
FASHIONABLE GATHERING.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon Alexandria’s smart set attended in full force the charming "At Home” on board the magnificent steamer “Osmanieh,” of the Khédivial Mail Line, which was gaily beflagged for the occasion. The visitors in- cluded Shefik Bey, of the Maieh, Mr. Gould, Mr. Scotides, Brewster Bey and Mrs. Brewster, Gedge Pasha, Beneducci Bey, the Commandant and officers of the local British Garrison, the Rev. Canon and Mrs. Ward, Mr. Barker, Mr. Silverdjeim. Mrs. Purser, Miss Peacock, Mr. Reginald Silley, Mr. Aquilina, the Misses Erba, and many other.
Owing to the indisposition of his wife the Governor of Alexandria was absent.

The officials of the Khédivial Mail Line and their wives were also present, including the popular manager, Mr. Parkinson, and his wife. The afternoon was spent in exploring the beauti- ful rooms of the ship, which was the object of general admiration.

An excellent buffet was placed at disposal of the guests on the upper deck, and the popping of champagne corks beat time very success- fully to the stirring strains of the band of the Dublin Fusiliers.

div.head: MR. SALVAGOS MOTOR ADVENTURE.
div.p: M. and Mme. Salvago have just arrived at Aix-les-Bains, "en auto.” from Paris. They had a very unpleasant experience just before getting there. On coming to a line of four or five hay wagons on the road they tried, very slowly, to pass them. As the automobile passed a man jumped directly in front from one of the wagons, and the inevitable happened. One of his legs was badly broken. Although there is a hospital at Culoz and several others near there they insisted upon bringing him to Aix, where he will have the best of care. They were greatly assisted by an American, who was on the road at the time, but who, after pacifying the crowd that colleoted, and taking M. and Mme. Salvago in his auto to make room for wounded man, disappeared without giving his name. M. and Mme. Salvago are at the Hotel d’Aix.

div.head: THE SHOUBRA MURDER.
div.p: The examination of witnesses continues before Judge Nettement, of the French Consular Court, and amongst others examined are M. Vasquez, judge of the court of contraven- tions, who gave evidence as to how M. Paillard senior spent the day of the crime. According to this witness, the father was at the Court at ten minutes past one o’clock, when he signed a procès-verbal countersigned by M. Vaeqarz.

Paillard junior, who is accused of the crime. having been employed at the Mixed Court, the examining magistrate desired of M. Varquez to furnish details as to his ante- cedents there, and regarding a matter in which he was mixed up.
M. Paillard senior was again questioned yesterday afternoon by M. Nettement.

div.head: TELEPHONITIS.
div.p: A new malady which will probably be known as telephonitis has been discovered in Paris, The principal subjects have been girls in the telephone service, and many of them have been compelled to abandon the service, and the ad- ministration is alarmed at the steady growth in the number of victims among the operators. The malady is supposed to be due to the cons- tant contract with electric currents, and it has been resolved to replace the women operators with men.

div.head: SANITARY ADMINISTRATION.
EXTRAORDINARY STATEMENTS.
COMPLAINTS IN ENGLAND.
div.p: We always regret whenever we see an English-run Administration of the Egyptian Government castigated in the Home Press. The latest victim of this kind of criticism is the Sanitary Administration, and a writer in the “Chemist and Druggist” brings some extra- ordinary charges against that Department. The “Chemist and Druggist” is the leading trade journal of the English pharmacists, and it is impossible to believe that such a serious journal would lend itself to false charges. But the allegations contained in this letter are very serious, as they imply a gross case of favour- itism. If the statement be true, that only one prospeotus had been handed over to a single favoured individual, the impression is a painful one. Of course we refuse to credit the truth of this charge, as no doubt the Administration will issue a categorical denial.
The following is the text of the article in question:—

“With a view to lessen the difficulties and to raise the status of the unqualified chemist in Egypt, the Sanitary Department (under whose auspices the chemists flourish here) informed us in July that they had arranged for examina- tions to take place in December next, when chemists assistants who have had five years’ experience and over would be given the opportunity of sitting, and those who passed would receive a certificate or permit entitling them to replace the qualified or responsible person in the shop during his unavoidable absence at meal times or through illness. This information was conveyed by means of a para- graph in a couple of the local daily papers, unsigned and unauthorised, evidently inserted by the editor as an item of information. By the same medium we were told that a prospec- tus or programme of the course of study would in a short while be available. An appli- cation to the Sanitary Department for a prospectus elicited the astonishing reply that one prospectus had been drawn up, and had been handed over to a private individual, who was prepared to coach candidates at the rate of L.E. 2 1/2 per month for the next four months, two lessons a week, in the evenings, starting at 10 p.m. and, further, the applicant was assured that all those who joined these classes were sure of passing. No other prospectus being available, and no other means of getting at the subjects for study, candidates are natur- ally obliged to join these classes, with the result that at present over thirty pupils attend them, among whom are some drawing a salary of L.E. 5/. to L.E. 6, of which they are obliged to pay one half for the next four months for eight lessons a month. On the other hand, suppose a man should be in a position to study up the subjects on his own account, his not knowing what these subjects are naturally debars him from sitting for the examination ; or should he wish to study with another coach at a cheaper rate, the same reason disqualifies him there. Superficially it would appear that this so-called modified examination, with its resulting certi- ficate, has been created not for the good of the public or the assistance of the "assistant un- qualified,” but what for?

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha will shortly come to Alexandria, where he will spend several weeks at Ras-el-Tin Palace.

Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan is staying now at Venine on board his yacht. Recently the Prince went on a motor car trip to Padua in company with Count Balbi Valier di Mouselice and made a number of excursions in the neighbourhood of that interesting Italian city.
Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, Governor General of the Sudan, is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 8th prox. on his return from Europe.
Major Elgood has returned to Egypt, and resumed his duties at the Ministry of the Interior,
Yessin Bey Mustapha, Mondir of Keneh, has now quite recovered from the effect of his recent motor-car misadventure, and resumed his official duties at Keneh yesterday.

Dr. Graham Bey, of the Sanitary Depart- ment, has arrived at Alexandria and remains here two or three days inspecting the City Public Health offices. Dr. Graham will shortly depart for England on leave.
Among the passengers booked at London on the P. and O. “Britannia” arriving at Port Said on the 12th inst. are Mr. John B. Caffari and family.

A party of Japanese gentlemen have arrived in Stamboul and are staying at the Pera Palace. Amongst them are Dr. Sagawa, pro- lessor of the Imperial School for the nobility at Tokio and Dr. J. Matsumura, professor of Botany at the University of Tokie and di- rector of the botanical gardens.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette”.

Sir, — I have been following with great interest the correspondence that has been aroused by the zealous efforts of our excellent Commandant of Police to grapple with one of the most serious of Alexandria’s problems. Miralai Hopkinson Bey appears to be inspired with the enthusiasm of a Mrs. Ormiston Chant and, aided as he is by the prayers of the Rev. Peter Rudolph and other good men, his devo- tion to the cause of social purity in Alexandria will long be remembered in the annals of this great (but wicked) city. At the same time I should suggest that the Alexandria City Police might vouchsafe some information to the public as to the programme of its purity campaign. It has, I believe, a special depart- ment organised with a view to coping with immorality, and at the present moment extra- ordinary activity appears to characterise that department. Only the other day I read an account in a letter in the "Gazette” of a strange sample of police interference with a respectable girl, and a few days afterwards “La Réforme” warned the police in very severe terms against the danger of excessive zeal and threatened to take up the matter if any further similar incidents recurred. Meanwhile the cam- paign against the unfortunate victims of this puritanical rigour still continues with un- abated energy, and in to-day’s “Phare d’Alex- andrie” the following paragraph is published under the title of "Verta officielle” : —
La police continue la recherche et la pour- suite des femmes de mœurs légères.
Le règlement concernant ces femmes est appliqué strictement par l’officier du bureau des mœurs.
Plusieurs femmes qui demeurent dans des quartiers habités par des bonnes familles ont été avisées d’avoir à déménager dans la plus bref délai.

The why and the wherefore of this police outburst of zeal for our morals are still un- known, for it cannot be alleged that Alex- andria’s morals have become so rapidly worse during the past few months as to necessitate such a crusade. In fact I know of no city in England with a population between a quarter and half a million that, so far as its streets are concerned, can compare favourably with Alexandria. The reasons for the present campaign are consequently still unknown un- less we are to suppose that Miralai Hopkin- son Bey has been urged on by the Rev. Peter Rudolph. In a recent letter from that philan- thropist (I am keeping a collection of this interesting correspondence) be remarks : —

“The Alexandria City Police ought to have taken up the matter many years ago, and I have for years and years past been urging the police to seriously start a crusade. How- ever, better late than never, and now that Miralai Hopkinson Bey has shown himself a zealous supporter of sexual propriety in Alex- andria, it is to be hoped that the good work will never slacken until Alexandria has been freed from its great reproach of one of the most immoral cities on the shores of the Medi- terranean.”

Judging from these words I must consider that the Rev. Peter Rudolph has urged on Miralai Hopkinson Bey to this crusade. But this does not prove that the police have any serious and exceptional grounds for their cam- paign. The only excuse for this “Crusade” is that it has helped to fill the columns of the "Egyptian Gazette” during the Silly Season with an amusing, if not instructive, correspon- dence.— I am, etc.
Alexandria, 5th September.
To the Editor of the “Egypt Gazette.”

Sir,—The hounding down of European women by the Moslem police, following the recent hang- ings and floggings, seems to be a sop thrown to the natives, who are now in joyful expecta- tion of the abolition of the Capitulations. Your anonymous correspondents appear to forget that virtue and vice are degrees of the same principle, just as mobility and and im- mobility are synonymous, or as the Rev. Peter Rudolph would put it, one tree in the garden produced fruit of the knowledge of good and evil.

If we be Christian, the words of the Master to the woman : “Where are thine accusers? neither do I acccuse thee, go in peace” should teach us not to harass and rail at our more sinned against than sinning sisters, who, though fallen, may have fought a better fight than we.
Against desperate temptation and over- whelming odds,
The world was their foe ere it knew them ;
It scattered its snares in their path,
Like a serpent it charmed and it drew them
Then met them with judgment and wrath!
O man ! I have sinned and have suffered,
The climax of evil is past,
But the justice of time may determine
That you were more guilty at last
R. KNIGHT FOLEY.
2, Chareh Abd-el-Daiem, Cairo.
September 4.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)
Londres étant venu en baisse de 1/4, la National Bank baisse également ici de 1/4 à 26 11/16 vendeurs.
L'Agricole perd 3/32 à 9 3/4.
En réaction aussi, quoique plus légère, le Comptoir à 6 15/32 la nouvelle, l'Union Fon- cière à 6 1/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien à 5 11/32 et la Delta Land à 3 15/32.
La Cassa di Sconto perd 75 centimes à 225 1/4 l'ancienne et 219 1/4 la nouvelle.
En revanche la Ramleh Railway gagne 3/16 à 7 3/8 acheteurs et le Trust 1/32 à 1 15/32.
Les Nungovish Hotels qui ont subi ces jours derniers une forte réaction, reprennent de 1/4 dès l'ouverture à 17 1/2, pour finir demandés à 17 3/8.
Les affaires ont été assez nombreuses en National Bank et Nungovich, mais en général il y eu peu-d'animation.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES.

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais a baissé hier de 1/8 à 87 et l'Unifiée de ¼ à 104 ½. Forte hausse sur la National Bank, qui est renseignée en avance d'une demi-livre à 27 ¼. L'Agricole a, par contre, perdu 1/8 à 9 ¾. La Daira a avancé de 1/8 à 16 7/8. Le Delta Light est restée invariée à 11 ¾.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a clôturé en reprise de 2 francs à 762. Le Banque d'Athènes a avancé de 1 france à 143.

La nouvelle, passablement inattendue, qu'une hausse de ½ livre s'est produite à Londres sur les actions de la National Bank of Egypt - hausse brusque dont on ignore encore les tenants et aboutissant - a eu pour effet heures d'enrayer le mouvement de réaction qui s'était dessiné hier en c'ôture sur notre marché des valuers.

Aussi bien l'ouverture de la séance de ce matin s'est faite dans de fort bonnes disposi- tions. La National Bank, qui avait clôturé asset faible la veille à 26 1/2 a débuté aux aborda de 27 pour revenir, sur des ventes, à 26 13/16-7/8 et clôturer à ce prix. L’Agricole, bien que renseignée pins faible à Londres, a avancé à 9 13/16 7/3. La Cassa di Sconto a été moins bien tenue à 226. La Banque d’Athènes a gagné 2 francs è 142-143.
Le Crédit Foncier a progressé à 760 761.
La part de fondateur Immobilière a rétro- gradé à 735. L'action Enterprise and Develop ment a bénéficié de 3/32 à 12 1/4.
En très bonne demande, les Improvements ont passé de 4 13/16 à 5 1/8-3/16. Le Wardan Estate s'est alourdi à 7 1/16. Les Héliopolis ont faibli à 316.
Les Jouiisanos Etax du Caire ont atteint 266-267. Les Automobiles ont avancé à 5 7/16 1/2. La part de fondateur Allotment est remontée à 130.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich out encore fléchi à 17 1/4. Les Egyptian sont revenus à 6 3/8-7/16. L'Anglo American Nile a fait 5 7/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land se sont consolidés à 3 7/16-1/2. Eu fort-bonne tenue, les Sait and Soda ont gagné plus d’un shelling à 21 sh. 6. Les New Egyptian se sont raffermis à 29 sh. 6 et les Markets à 25 sh.
Rien de particulier à relever sur les autres titres de la cote.

Faute d'espace nous sommes obligés de ren- voyer à demain la publication de quelques données fort intéressantes, qn’on nous transmet d'Alexandrie, sur l'actif de l’Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. (Glymenopoulo), actif qui passe à la Building Lands of Egypt Co. par suite de la fusion définitive des deux Sociétés.

La formation d’une nouvelle Société anonyme pour l'Egypte a été enregistrée A Londres le 27 Août dernier. Son objet est d’acquérir l'entreprise de La Nile Transport Co, Société égyptienne constituée au Caire en 1903 ; de passer un arrangement avec cette Société d'une part, et J. G. Chakour Pacha, C. I. Nicole, E. Manusardi, G. Spetzoropoulo, W. Ablitt, V. Coronal, G. Miniakis et T. N. Coressy-Kores sios d’autre part, et N. Ayoub (pour la Com- pagnie) en troisième part ; et d’entreprendre en Egypte et ses dépendances toutes affaires concernant le transport des marchandises par voie fluviale et par terre, etc.
Le capital social est de £100,000 représenté per 24,900 actions ordinaires de £1 et 8,000 parts de fondateur à 1 shelling.
Le premier conseil d’administration est com- posé de MM. Chakour Pacha, C. Nicole, E Manusardi, G. Spetxeropoulo, W. Ablitt, V. Coronel, G. Miniakis et Core ay-Koressios.

Les bénéfices seront partagés comme suit: après prélèvement de 5% pour dépréciation du matériel, etc., il sera attribué 6 % aux actions ordinaires comme premier dividende et 5% pour la formation d'un fonds de réserve. Sur le solde, il sera alloué 2% au président et 3% à être divisé entre les autres membres du conseil d’administration. Sur l’excédent, 60% seront attribués aux actions de capital comme divi- dende supplémentaire, et 40 % eux parts de fondateur.
D'aprés on avis officiel de la Banque d’A- thènes, il a été décidé de procéder comme suit pour la répartition des actions de la nouvelle émission de cet établissement decrédit:
Pour les souscriptions inférieures à 15 actions, l'attribution sera intégrale; poor celles au-dessus de 15 actions, il sera réparti le 3/4 pour cent aux souscripteurs.

Il ressort du dernier état comparatif publié par la Brasserie des Pyramides que les recettes provenant de la vente de bière et de glace, du 1er Janvier à fin Août 1906, se sont élevées à L.E. 19,196 contre 16,728 en 1905, soit en surplus de LE 2,468 pour l’exercice courant.

div.head: RUSSIA.
GOVERNMENT’S POLICY.
div.p: An official communiqué describing the Go- vernment's policy announces that severer me- thods of repression of revolutionary crimes will be resorted to. It promises liberal reforms, including the removal of useless restrictions on the Jews, the granting of National Assemblies to Poland and the Baltic provinces, and the reform of the police and other public services. (Reuter)

An official communication explains the Go- vernment programme, announcing measures for quelling the revolution, the study of anto- nomy for the provinces, the summoning of the Zemstvos, and an income tax. (Havas)

div.head: CRETE.
PETITION TO THE POWERS.
div.p: The majority of the members of the Cretan Assembly have telegraphed to the Powers asking for the continuance of Prince George of Greece as their Commissioner. The Prince has issued a message to the Cretans urging pa- tience, and declaring that the Powers are doing all that is possible to ameliorate their lot. (Reuter)

div.head: SENSATIONAL APPOINTMENT.
COLONIES RUN ON BUSINESS LINES.
div.p: A sensation has been created throughout Germany by the appointment of Herr Dern- burg, a well known banker and business man, as director of the Colonial Department, in succession to Herr Hohenlohe, who has resign- ed in consequence of the severe criticisms of his management of the department. Herr Dernburg’s appointment is regarded as indi- cating the determination of the Emperor Wil- liam to run the German colonies on busiess lines. (Reuter)

div.head: THE CUBAN REVOLT.
FAILURE OF NEGOTIATIONS.
div.p: All attempts to negotiate with the insur- gents have failed. The outlook is unpromising. (Reuter)

div.head: THE BRITISH LEGATION TO PERSIA
div.p: Mr. Spring-Rice, the British Minister at Teheran, has started for Persia. (Reuter)

div.head: COLLIERY STRIKE IN WALES.
UNHEARD OF RUFFIANISM.
div.p: Extraordinary scenes were witnessed in connection with a strike of miners in South Wales. Id order to protest against the employ- ment of non members of the Union, a mob of women raided the houses of the non members, whom they dragged out and stripped and cover- ed with blacklead. They threw some of them into the river and marched others in their shirts through the streets. (Reuter

div.head: ROYAL VISITORS TO DENMARK.
div.p: Queen Alexandra and the Dowager-Empress of Russia have arrived. (Reuter

div.head: MR. HALDANE RETURNS.
div.p: Mr. Haldane has returned. (Reuter)

div.head: DEATH OF SPITZEL.
div.p: M. Louis Spitzel, the European Adviser of Li-Hung-Chang, died here. (Reuter)

div.head: RACING.
div.p: St. Leger Stakes.-Sancy has been scratched. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SULTAN’S CARES.
HIS HEAD TASTER.
THE ALBANIA SENTRY.
div.p: The Palace of Yildiz stands on the top of a hill, and is surrounded by a thick wall. It is almost a misnomer to call it a palace, as "Yildiz" comprises a number of very modest- looking whitewashed villas and kiosques, any one of which is more like a private residence than the home of a sovereign. The study in which Abdul Hamid passes a third of his life is furnished with a simplicity amounting almost to poverty. On the big writing table lie the papers and documents of the day only, which are carried off as soon as they have been attended to. The role is that nothing should remain more than 24 hours on that table, and there is no wastepaper basket.

His favourite room is his library, or libra- ries, of which he has four. The first Imperial library was founded by Sultan Ahmed III. One of them is devoted exclusively to works on Turkey and the Ottoman dominions in all lan- guages. It contains a strange collection of manuscripts of books which have never been published, that were bought up in order to prevent their circulation. Another section is composed of works in Turkish, Arabic, and Persian, and these are kept in the best order, as the librarians can read the titles and catalo- gue them regularly, which they are incapable of doing with foreign productions.

The Sultan's day begins early. In summer at five and winter at six he rises, and if the weather is fine goes immediately into the park. This is extensive and laid out in alleys and little forests with several artificial lakes, the largest of which has an island in the mid- dle. On this big pond his Majesty generally embarks in a caique, or boat, which he rows himself, or in either a small steam or electric launch, and repairs to the island to visit his pets. These are of all sorts—stags, roedeer, gazelles, rare goats, and sheep, and birds of every land. They are all tame, and are said to be very fond of their royal master.

At ten o’clock the Sultan returns to his room and takes a frugal breakfast. He is served by the head butler, Osman Effendi, who tastes each dish before handing it to his master, and nobody else is present, unless it be, rarely, some of the children. After break- fast an hour or so is spent in the library, where the illustrated books are most used. Altogether there are some 10,000 volumes. At one o’clock punctually his Majesty retires to his bed-room for a siesta, whilst one of the eunuchs ora picked man of the Albanian Guard stands outside the door.

This is really the best rest he gets, as he often works late into the night, and then goes tired to bed. The siesta lasts an hour and a half, when he is softly waked, and at half-past two repairs to the study for the labours of State. Here he works uninterruptedly, often till past midnight, with the exception of the time taken for a hasty refreshment about sun- set. All documents brought to him are first thrown into a disinfecting box, and then given to him by the First Secretary, Tahsin Bey.

div.head: TURKEY AND THE POWERS.
div.p: The Turkish Empire exists on sufference. It is our desire that the Sultan’s authority shall remain undiminished so long as he uses it with reasonable regard for the interests of his sub- jects and with some sign of respect for the de- mands of a spreading civilisation. He can- not altogether close the gates of Turkey to the spirit of modern progress and enlightenment. —"The Standard."

div.head: SAMARITANS' APPEAL
div.p: There are now in London seeking sympathy and financial aid from the Hebrew community four leading members of a religions body which, reduced to a couple of hundred members, has historical grounds to be considered the oldest Semitic sect—the Samaritans. The Rev. Dr. M. Gaster is bringing their claims before his so-religionists, and he has outlined some interesting facts concerning their history and present condition. As a world wide authority on Hebraic studies, he also stands alone as the possessor of a complete sopy of the Sama- ritan Pentateuch in English. Their books of Moses differ from the accepted Jewish text in two main particulars. One is an addition to the Commandments, while their version of a passage in Deuteronomy relates that it was on Mount Gerizim in Shechem,and not on Mount Ebal, that J shua was commanded to set up the stones, thus claiming that the Jews had altered the Hebrew text after the schism, making Jerusalem, and not Shechem, the place selected for the Sanctuary.

On the bills of Nablus the little community have consistently maintained the separate career on which they started in the year 432 before the common era. The head of the deputation, conspiouous in striking Oriental costume, is Ishak ben-Amram ba-Cohen ba-Levi, the son of the late priest and next in succession on reaching tin required age. They bring with them relics of ancient days, one being a venerable scroll used in the synagogne, enclos- ed in the ornamental case described by several noted archaeologists, and some modern manu- scripts in the beautiful old Samaritan charac- ters. All can read and write Samaritan as well as Arabic, and all have been educated in the hillside school on whose behalf they now seek funds. One feature peculiar to the Samaritans is that to this day they sacrifice the paschal lamb on the feast of the Passover.

div.head: "AN EGYPTIAN SINBAD."
THE OLDEST SEAMANS' YARN.
div.p: Professor Goleniescheft, of St. Petersburg, has published in the current number of the “Recueil des Travaux” the hieroglyphic text and translation of a most interesting papyrus now in the collection of the Hermitage Museum. The papyrus was found at Feshen some years ago, hat has not been hitherto published on account of the difficulty of re- producing the red ink in which it was written. The document purports to be the report of a most adventurous voyage, made by an Egyp- tian captain, who wishes to be introduced to the Court of Pharaoh, in order to relate to his Majesty the wonders be encountered. The colophon which is appended at the end enables us to date the composition with considerable certainty. It reads : "It is written from the beginning to the end by the scribe of cunning fingers, Ameni-amen-ra may ; he lived a life or prosperity and health.” This name marks it as a work of the period of the Twelfth Dynasty, about B.C. 2800, a time when Egypt was beginning to expand its power and trade beyond the Nile Valley. The ancient mariner begins by saying : "I was going to the mines of Pharaoh, in a ship of one hundred and fifty cubits, with one hundred and fifty sailors, who had seen Heaven and Earth, and whose hearts were stronger than lions.” Truly, a band of fearless venturers ; but ill fate awaited them. "The wind rose and threw up mighty waves, but as for me 1 seized a piece of wood, but all who were in the vessel perished, not one re- maining."

The shipwrecked man was washed ashore on an island, and after three days began to search for food. It appears from the account that it was no desert island, but one rich in food of fruits, herbs, and all manner of good things, and the sailor ate his full, and "made an offering to the gods" in his gratitude. Scarcely had he finished his meal when a Dew adventure awaited him. "Sud- denly," he says, "I heard a noise as of thunder and the earth shook.” He then saw drawing near to him "a huge serpent of terrible aspect, his body overlayed with gold, his colour of bright lapis lazuli." .The serpent, however, appears to have been a kindly beast, for after asking how he came to the island, he opened his mouth and carried him to his resting- place, where he finds a tribe of serpents, seventy five in all. We now come to a most valuable passage. The serpent king says : "If thou hast come to me, it is God who has let me live. It is he who has brought thee to this ‘isle of the blest,' where nothing is lacking and which is filled with all good things." This reference at so early a period to the 'isle of the blest" Professor Goleniescheft points out as showing how old is this tradition, which appears in later Egyptian, Greek, and Arabic tradition. The serpent king tells his guest that after three months "a ship shall come from thine own land.” Like many another mariner, this Egyptian sailor waits anxiously, and climbs a tall tree to watch for the ship, and he runs in haste to tell his kind serpent, but he finds that, with the proverbial know- ledge of that reptile, he knows all about it. The rescued one is not allowed to go away empty-handed. The king says : "Farewell, go to thy house, and see thy little children again ; let thy name be good in thy town ; these are my wishes for thee.” Full of grati- tude, the sailor promises to mention the king Pharaoh, and return with a ship of treasures "such as are fit for a god a friend of men in a far off land." The answer of the serpent is valuable. “ When thou shall depart from this place, thou shall never more see this isle, for it will be changed into waves.” Such are the main details of this document, but amid the romance it is possible to trace some solid substratum of truth. The islands filled with serpents may have some basis if we suppose that the voyage had not been on the open sea, but up the Nile to the regions about Khartoum and the Bahr-el-Ghazal. Here the voyager would come upon the great marshes and the islands of sudd or vegetation, which, at that remote period, would be swarming with serpents and the great amphibia.

In the time of the kings of the twelfth dynasty, especially in the time of Sankhkara and Amenemhat I., many half military, half trading expeditions were sent up the Nile, and no doubt the voyagers returned with many a mariner’s yarn. These floating islands, often covered with vegetation, and even trees, during storms or heavy floods became saturated and sank out of sight, as the Serpent King predic- ted. This idea of the locality is indicated when we see the presents which the sailor brings away. "Precious perfumes of Cassia, of sweet woods, kohl, abundance of incense, ivory tusks, baboons and apes,” all of which are products of Nubia and the Upper Nile. The time occupied in the journey, three months each way, would be about the time required, and certainly not sufficient for a voyage to Punt or Somaliland on the open sea. No doubt these ancient navigators, like those of more modern times, told these tales of strange adventure partially to deter others and to keep to themselves the ancient El Dorados of Africa, and also to give an exalted idea of their bra- very. Professor Goleniescheft says it is probable that it was some such ancient seaman's yarn, coming in after years as part of the flotsam and jetsam of folk-lore, which formed the basis of the story of Sinbad the Sailor. That this charming story of the Arabian Nights is one composed of old stories gathered from many sources is beyond doubt. Two incidents can be traced to Old Babylonian sources. The great Rokh bird that carries the hero away is evi- dently a survival of the story of Etana trying to fly to heaven holding on to an eagle, a legend which was borrowed in Hebrew folk-
lore, and attached to the deeds of Nimrod, and later by the Pseudo-Callisthenes attributed to Alexander the Great. So also the story of the Valley of Diamonds is an echo of the episode in the Chaldean epic, where Gilgarnes-Nimrod visits the distant Western mountains, where the sun sets guarded by scorpion men, and comes to the garden of jewels, where the leaves of the trees and the birds' nests are full of precious stones. Stories live on in the East for centuries, passing from nation to nation, and many a tale of old Egypt or older Chaldea found its way by strange routes into the bean- tiful literature of the "Thousand and One Nights.”

div.head: MAN SELLS HIS SKIN.
div.p: A novel business transaction has just been concluded at Milan. There are two patients in the Brescia Hospital, one of whom had rather less skin than he required, and the other had some to spare. A satisfactory arrangement was come to between thorn for the sale and purchase of the superfluous integument. Antonio Gilberti, a coachman, had the mis- fortune to injure his leg badly about a year ago. The surgeons managed to save the injured limb, but the nature of the wounds left it prectically skinless. It was patched up more or less with bits of epidermis taken from other parts of the coachman’s body, but unfortunately for him, he could not spare enough to complete the job, and the repairs had to be suspended for lack of material. At this stage another patient, named Franceschini, came to the rescue. He had more skin than he required for his own personal use, and he offered to sell the coachman some. A bargain was struck, and for some weeks the doctors have been flaying Franceschini and grafting the removed portions on Gilberti’s leg. These have rooted nicely, and the coachman will shortly be able to leave hospital with his nether limbs in a normal condition, so far as integument is con- cerned. The price paid for the grafted skin has not been disclosed.

div.head: AN EGG ‘FAKING” FACTORY.
div.p: The Chicago officials now engaged on a "pure food” campaign have discovered a large factory devoted to the "reprocessing" of eggs that have, to put it mildly, passed their prime. The place, the "New York Herald” states, was closely guarded and difficult to locate, but detective*. with ordinary olfactory acumen, had no difficulty in arriving at the right spot. Eggs hopelessly beyond all chance of sale in the markets are mixed in great vats, run over huge wooden rollers, deodorised, dried, and sifted and finally consigned to bakers all over the country for cooking purposes. Owing to the nature of the business only the initials of firms buying the staff are pot upon the packages.

div.head: AMERICAN GIRL'S VIEWS OF EUROPE.
div.p: The forty Kentucky belles who scamped across Europe and have reached home tired but happy, have expressed their opinions on what they saw with engaging candour. They think that the Scotch were the most cordial, the Englishmen the best-looking, English women the sweetest but the worst dressed, with the longest and flattest feet, and the Parisiennes the most artificial and with the most-false hair they encountered. French- men they describe as “undersized, most given to staring, and the rudest." The Belgians are “picturesque,” while the Germans are voted to be the most sterling and sincere. The belles arrive at the conclusion that, "after all said and done, America is the best country ever invented, and Kentucky God’s own State.”

div.head: THE MAN WHO DIDN’T TIP.
div.p: The fate of a prosperous German hotel pro- prietor, who believed that the tip ought to be abolished, and tried the experiment of living up to his principles on tour, is instructively set forth by the Lausanne correspondent of the “Daily Mail." One week of it in Germany and Switzerland was enough for Herr Graner’s wife and daughter, who abandoned the tour in disgust, and three weeks have converted Graner himself to the invincibility of the tipping system. Everywhere his coming appears to have been signalled, by some such arrange- ment of cabalistic marks as that which thieves and cadgers employ to warn their friends of dangerous or useless houses. No one ever met Herr Grauer at a station, or saw him and his luggage into an omnibus. He had garments lost and spoiled ; he was served last at dinner; he had to ring half an hour for hot water, which proved to be cold ; and no one would do anything for him. It is well that a man of moral courage and a tough German constitu- tion has tried the experiment, but few will think of following his example. Those odd francs or marks have now been proved to be the only way to make a holiday "go.”
